The food amazing, Truffle Mac n Cheese, Amazing Neo-French Cuisine, Delish Crepes. Just plain yummy!

3AhnJZ0X3DP-ClUJhTmmXA.text: I came out here for brunch.  The line wasn't too long, and we were able to get inside in less than 30 minutes.  The food itself wasn't too bad.  However, there is no reason why there should be sushi at a French-themed buffet.  Ugh. :|  The desserts though ... Oh man, I would definitely come back for that.

b_NtY4Z1yYLy3ob1p0_3Wg.text: Le Village proves that you don't have to have the biggest and most extravagant spread (that would be Bacchanal at Caesar's) to provide a thoroughly enjoyable experience.   As of October 2013, Le Village is the only buffet in Vegas that offers reservations through Open Table.  When you have a reservation, you by pass the line and go through a separate entrance parlor that is also used by Total Rewards Platinum and Diamond members.   Waiting in line for 30 minutes to an hour for a buffet really stinks but with our reservation, we didn't wait at all!  And we were 15 minutes late for our reserved time.  One member of our party had Platinum status so it allowed us to use the special check in desk even if we hadn't had a reservation.  It also enabled us to be seated in a special area where we received special service.  What "special service" might you ask?  Our server was extra friendly but the great thing is that she offered to bring us steamed crab legs to our table!  At Le Village, the "common people" schlep up to the buffet line to help themselves and pick through the crab legs which are served cold.  Unlike at Bacchanal, where you can request the crab legs to be boiled and served hot, Le Village doesn't offer warm steamed crab legs except for the "status" diners.  And she brought hot bowl after bowl of hot juicy crab legs until we begged her to stop!  Being brought crab legs directly to your table elevates a buffet dining experience beyond the normal and makes dining so much more enjoyable.  After having gorged on so many crab legs, we only had enough room leftover to sample a few other dishes.  The only reason that I don't give Le Village 5 stars is because the selection of dishes doesn't rival that of Bacchanal.  But I actually did enjoy the crab legs better at Le Village because they were brought to our table and also they are not salty, unlike at Bacchanal.  Aside from the food, we also loved the slightly kitschy atmosphere of the French village.  The macarons and other desserts were very good (albeit not a huge variety like Bacchanal) and instead of standard soft serve, they offer frozen custard, which has a slightly different texture and richer taste.  At the end of our meal, our server brought to our table of 5 people 10 chocolate bar lollipops shaped like the Eiffel Tower, 5 dark chocolate and 5 white chocolate.  We later saw these identical treats in a gift shop in the hotel for $3.50 each!   I'd highly recommend getting Platinum status so that you can enjoy the benefits!  If you don't want to gamble a lot to earn your status, you can instantly get Platinum status if you apply for and get approved for the Total Rewards credit card.

bEv95tPh3NzFVbhnGJQ5hA.text: So much better than I remembered.  Last time we had breakfast here and it was horrible.  This time, we tried dinner.   24 hour buffet pass for $40...how can you go wrong?  Except after the 2nd buffet, you really want to run straight towards a toilet or grab a roll of Tums.  Seriously, no one should be eating more than one buffet within 24 hours.  Heck with it all though, this is Vegas...the city of losing wages and eating just as much as you freakin can!  This was our 3rd buffet on our pass...a dinner stop.   Highlights:   CREPES!!!  Yummy delicious crepes...I take em plain with some powdered sugar. Really nice lady making em...the crepes were perfectly chewy...I had 2.  Ugh.   Seafood.  A combination of crab, shrimp, mussels, and clams.  Not the greatest...but good enough.  Dessert.  Probably the biggest display out of all the buffets we went to.  They're your usual buffet fare...nothing was really wow but enough to satisfy your dessert craving.   The duck was also pretty good...it was made with orange sauce and rice pilaf.  Can't think of any of the other standouts as the buffets mostly had the same things.    Pretty decent buffet...#3 on our buffet list.

AnA1kFGUlVTuXRvsYeUhtw.text: This place has been the best buffet I have been to yet!  The mashed potatoes are worth the price by themselves!   The have steak, chicken, turkey, etc...  The crab legs are amazing also, they cut them length wise down the shell so there is no need to open them yourself. Just grab and eat.  I will definitely be back here on my next trip.

RI-s0ElBY6g6Bj8PnbzFjQ.text: Hidden Gem! This blissful joint is the best secret on the strip as far as breakfast is concerned. If you are staying near paris, ballys, etc., you must have breakfast here. Many options, everything has a unique french twist to it. Not your everyday back home breakfast, lots of unique flavors. Sure they have the usual eggs, sausage, etc. But they have dozens of uniquely french and european creations as well. Only problem is the high likelihood of over eating... But hey, when in Rome... Enjoy... You're welcome!

oHd9zzwVaUeYlaorpz2jNA.text: We ate here 3 days in a row.  You have to try the crepe. Rosendo at the crepe station was super nice and he was the only one that put hazelnuts on the banana Nutella crepe, yum!  Armando at the Omellete station is the man- he is super friendly, efficient and funny! Talk about great customer service.  I would go back here again.

Cw2Z69otZsjV1bsLM4k8IA.text: First thing you do before visiting le village -- buy a groupon ($44 for two for dinner with a bottle of wine)  Second thing you must do before coming here is book your table on Opentable. If you make a reservation through them you go through the VIP section instead of standing in line (and the line was long!)  Overall, the buffet was pretty good, especially for the groupon price. Everything seemed a bit salty, but because none of us had eaten yet we all inhaled everything. The only thing that really stood out to me was the deserts. Both the creme brulee and the flan were amazing! None of us waited for the crepes, but they also looked really good.  I probably won't be coming back if I have to pay full price, but if you can still snag the groupon definitely go!

VV9iz_mHpFgkTcsrIFFP2g.text: Mediocre at best...  Came here for Sunday brunch around noon. Line wasn't too bad, got in after a 35 minute wait.   GOOD: -The seating area is cute, with a few off rooms to dine in aside from the main area.   BAD: -Food was just mediocre, small selection and unimpressive -Service was poor -Dessert bar was very unimpressive. The macaroons tasted stale and the ice cream selection was just soft serve ice cream I could get at McDonalds.   Not worth your time and money while in Vegas!

LNqKX-Sy4FAkcsyqKybuCg.text: Years ago, we came here for dinner buffet, and this time we came here for breakfast buffet with Buffet of Buffets (BoB) pass. The breakfast items tasted good and I think I like the breakfast more than their dinner. There was nothing fancy but got some good breakfast items that were freshly made. We got to choose hot chocolate as our drinks as well.  It was an ok breakfast buffet, but not something I would crave for. It's probably our first and last breakfast buffet there.

t4iUryj0NfSBZGW-JdtAJw.text: Ate dinner here 2 out of 5 nights.  Moderate price for Vegas.  End cut prime rib to die for.  Have paid upward of $40 for lesser quality.  Endless cold (and not soggy) shrimp and king crab legs.  Great choices, beverages included, and desserts are quite good.  Love the frozen custard instead of the iced milk others call ice cream.  Well done!!!

G6ni3W6R13q80Z8IeuuXKQ.text: This is my favorite buffet I've had so far!  The prime rib was perfectly done.  The sides all have a great French touch and full of flavor.  Any of the custard desserts was to die for.  I highly recommend going and you will get above what you pay for!!!  I can't wait to go again.

gMCbZ8Lcq4ZSA0KqsUpFSg.text: So glad we spotted this place while touring through the Paris Las Vegas. We were planning on swinging out to the Four Kegs (see my previous review) for Stromboli, but took a peek in this place. The ambiance and setting were just too much for the wife and our friend to not check out the fare. After poking around the stations we opted to pay the $23 ($20 w/ a player's card) for lunch.  The food was fantastic and they had quite an assortment to choose from. Some of our highlights / favorites were:  Braised Pork Belly Andouie Sausage Chateaubriand style tri-tip brie & bacon Macaroni and Cheese Capatavi w/ truffle oil and mushrooms  The prime rib was also to die for: medium-rare and super tender / moist!  Many veggies to choose from, including perfectly roasted asparagus!  They offered an assortment of seafood; including stuffed sole, mussels, clams and shrimp.  They had a savory and sweet crepe station, for those who enjoy crepes (we did not partake, however).  As for dessert they had some of the usual fare one would find at a buffet, but here they had three items that are hard to come by (and in which we indulged): creme brulee, French style (lemon infused) macaroons (light & fluffy), and custard (not soft serve ice cream).  To make a long short, we definitely got our monies worth! We are already planning to eat here again, on our next LV trip, with our son and his fiancee! The dinner menu looks awesome (includes duck!). The wife and I concurred that we would give this restaurant (buffet) five (5) stars!   They MUST have REAL chefs working here, not the "usual" hired off the street types who simply follow the establishment's recipes (which usually = WTF).                                                       Bon appetit!

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. prime rib and tr-tip combo!
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Braised Pork Belly in squared pan!

-idwlBh4TOeB6Vc0Kufi2w.text: We visited Le Village early on a Thursday night and were not sure what to expect based on the varying Yelp reviews. However, I must say that both my wife and I were pleasantly surprised.   The wait was nearly nonexistent (it was early Thursday after all), and we were seated within five minutes despite having no reservation. Our server was friendly, but was clearly having to man a lot of duties, as it was a good 10 minutes between each visit.   But of course any buffet lives and dies on the food, and the fare here ranges from average to surprisingly good. The highlights were the fantastic crepe station ("Le Singe", a banana and hazelnut crepe, was excellent), the flan, which was some of the best I've had buffet or otherwise, and the seafood offerings like bouillabaisse and arrabiata mussels. The other entries were all passable to good, and I cleared all three plates.   The price might be a touch high, especially with the Bellagio across the street for a few dollars more, but I actually preferred this buffet to the Wynn which we are in the same week. It's a quaint French countryside take on the Vegas buffet and a fair choice for your bachanalian endulgence.

_KuBZDel9d_56J8nmad5fA.text: I went for the lunch for the price of breakfast on Monday ($3 dollars in saving) at 10:45 a.m.  This is my 4th visit. The other times were all dinners. The lunch is awesome and we found an empty table in the box seats section and the waiter was able to make arrangement for us, a party of four. Try the prime rib steak. It was done just right and very juicy and tender. I went back to ask for another order. Also their crapes are excellent.  Only downside is the sushi section, they all looked withered and are not in a serving size (they are like half a roll). Oh well, this is supposed to be French but not Asian, anyhow.  It was quite an experience.

atJ-SVVsUZ0lslwXFM4gYg.text: Saving grace was the crepes. Meat was tough,  rubbery and somewhat flavorless, cake was dry.  Crepes were awesome though. They saved the rating.

EVodzRxto4sriRLHQ2XR9g.text: Save your time in Vegas & go elsewhere. I was disappointed we wasted a 'buffet day' on this place.  As someone who follows a Vegan diet, I was looking forward to the salad bar which was an embarrassment. The salad bar was clearly not kept up with or replenished at all, even when the food was low. I was grossed out just by thinking of how many hours those salads have been sitting out there. It was completely abandoned (the dim lighting didn't help). The baked desserts reportedly had the same problem as the salad bar (stale).   Although, others in my party seemed to enjoy the seafood options & crepe bar! I can say the food they kept hot was good such as their roasted vegetables and pastas.  The service was extremely slow, the hardest part of the meal was hunting someone down for new utensils or a cup of water.  Lunch for $24.99 was alright, not worth it if you're vegan IMO. I rather shell out a few extra dollars & head over to the Bacchanal buffet across the street (fresh juice!).

s7i9NmJk7QWtRHyxlVocng.text: Below average experience for a buffet. The bouillabaisse is the best dish, good amount of seafood with a nice stew. There's some sushi but doesn't look very appetizing. Tri-tip steak is tough and my jaw got tired chewing. Bread was stale, and for a French themed hotel that's a huge no-no. I went around 2pm and most of the food looked like it had been sitting around for a while. Was curious before but now disappointed. Value isn't there for being 25$ a person.

7JTPk5NxxSW-j1lIZhUNtQ.text: I was really looking forward to some awesome French food at this buffet... but besides the crepes and creme brulee, I really didn't find any. It was really disappointing and my dad kept complaining about the lack of variety of food options too.  There was a huge line but we opted to pay $10 more for the 'express' line which was not worth it. We definitely would've crossed the street for some Bellagio buffet goodness instead and give them the extra $10 bucks.  The service was crappy too, I felt bad for the servers who were mostly older ladies. I saw one of them limping while she walked and it was worse because she had to carry heavy-ass plates and cups back and forth. She even came by to tell us that she was exhausted from working since 6 am that morning (it was 3 pm at the time). And because of that, I shall forgive her for pouring my requested apple juice into the cup that used to hold my dad's orange juice. No wonder it tasted funky.  My favorite part was definitely the creme brulee and crepes as others have mentioned. My dad really liked the cocktail shrimp, he said he's never seen such a clean shrimp before.  The place was cute and everything but the buffets at the Wynn and Bellagio are definitely more worth your money.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crepe and creme brulee

YVov-KPWbLdh5GZ1Q0oyIQ.text: A very reliable buffet with a wide variety of tasty fare ... Unique is the freshly made crepes station choose from a menu of sweet or savory options delicious

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Freshly made bananas foster crepe with hazelnuts and Nutella!

_wKeACrND3VvuTfAU_OHxA.text: TIP - First glass of wine is complimentary. Why not?  TIP - Crepes are good. But if you're not so crazy about it being folded not in half, but around the filling, tell the chef beforehand how you want it done. I wanted just sugar, lemon and butter. Made! TIP - Macarons and creme brulee are freshly made! Must have.  TIP - if it's not crowded, you can ask the hostess if you can have your preference of seat - next to a wall or out in the open.  What I don't like - Food can be a bit too greasy/oily for my taste. Also, it's hard to flag down your waitress. So order twice your drinks when you get seated!

B35bASIpbCOcOlz6wXfj7w.text: Awesome, such an upgrade from the flamingo which I tried earlier. The crepes were just phenomenal. Had the banana, hazelnut and Nutella crepe first then the berry crepe with strawberries, blueberries, raspberries  and whipped cream. These were both fantastic. They had all sorts of fresh stations for carvings and breakfast meats. This is the place for breakfast but get there early, by 10:30 the line was 40 people deep to get in and not moving

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Line by 10:30 Am for breakfast
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sticky buns
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nutella and banana crepe

37ztBmfM7iZ0vUzLp1KTpw.text: Hmmm...I'd really like to give this place a 2 1/2 primarily because of my disappointment, but I think in all fairness the food is just fine.  5 years ago, I loved this place. 2 years ago I liked this place. This month....ehhhhh it was ok.  There used to be dishes like beef bourguignon, and coq au vin which made this a unique experience. Lots and lots and lots of different grilled veggies too and great salads. This time around, significantly less veggies (yes I know a lot of people don't go to buffets for veggies), and neither of my favorite dishes. This time around the food seemed like the stuff you find at any other buffet...nothing unique, and the quality was just ok.  The duck was dry.   People really seem to love the abundance of crab legs, and that may be my problem...I don't really eat crab. But the abundance is definitely there for those that are interested.  There are still long lines, and still less than personable service (but nothing overtly rude...just ok).  The desserts have expanded a bit over the years, but they were just ok.  Wicked Spoon across the street had better (according to the partner who loves desserts, but also cares about the taste more than the presentation).     The price is a bit lower than say the Bellagio, so all in all probably not a bad deal. I'd go early though at the dinner hour, to avoid the ridiculously long line...you'll just have the semi-ridiculously long line.   After being a fan of this buffet for many years though, will be branching out next time to try something new.

PUwL5QfMNgIuoSOCTvLsSQ.text: Ok this may be my favorite buffet in all of Las Vegas. They have the best frozen yogurt I have ever had, let me just start there, A FroYO station!!! There is tons of variety and because this buffet is at The Paris, there is a large selection of Parisian options as well, to make you feel right at home. The whole Paris hotel and casino has this really fun outdoor theme going on so sitting in their dining room is like sitting in a Paris courtyard...kind of ;)

yIWJZYbC7Fed2bo-wH538w.text: In short form, overpriced, long waits, and average service.  Having been to the Bellagio buffet earlier on our Vegas trip, the Buffet at Paris can't really compare at all. If you want to try multiple buffets, head to the Bellagio buffet last. We waited for the brunch buffet at 11:30am and proceeded to make no progress for the most part after 45 minutes. Diamond card members get the express treatment and causes the regular line to move twice as slow. The only saving grace for this buffet were the crepes, but even that's to say it's only better than the other food available.   Bottom line, if you're in to 29.99 average crepes, this place is for you. Oh yeah, there's only one stall in the womens room (use the restrooms before or after the buffet in the main casino).

LUwyw1PPXl0xmMeMNdYjlA.text: This place is a lot cheaper than the top end buffets. Food was pretty good for a buffet - if you really want to be *savoring* rather than *shoving* food down your gullet then don't go to a buffet.   Also, it's really only worth coming here for brunch/lunch. Can't really have crepes for dinner...or can you?

qMiLqiqfUirbPy4Gdz3QfQ.text: Pro's - Good food.  Con's - Long line for brunch.              Service was terrible.  Been to this buffet roughly about 10 times.  Even though the wait is horrible and the service bad, the food is worth it for me to come back.

fkNWQ1EwWziZ7S3QbTG8ng.text: There was a wait at lunch, about 25 minutes give or take, definitely doable, though unnecessary because they had tons of tables. I guess they think that's acceptable to people so they don't pay for more waiters. The food was excellent and great quantity of choices. Very satisfied.

n9X7IDadFI2WSDqMc4YVNw.text: Super Bowl weekend with the guys and we do 2 buffets a day, it is embarassing but that is what we do. We did Bellagio, Mandalay Bay and Paris.  Paris buffet review is for breakfast/lunch.  It was winner hands down.  Mandalay Bay is looking old, did have King Crab legs that were sliced in half at dinner the remaining selection was weak. I would pass.  As for Paris, we ate there twice, wished we had gone for dinner over MBay.  Nice combination of everything, homemade crepes were nice, wide variety of carnivore foods, carbs, carbs carbs, little cups of creme brulee quite yum.  Bellagio buffet seemed over rated.. on a side note cannot believe that there were 5 people playing blackjack at a $300 a hand minimum table at Bellagio.. what do those people do for work ! sign me up!

0mCEboX2h33HR1ooMD_Kug.text: One of the top 5 buffets in Buffet Town. Wonderful decor and well thought-out food stations with tasty selections make for a great dining adventure in outdoor Paris. The desserts alone are worth the trip to to this quaint village.

8aahMCxzbDc_3KjoAwfv6Q.text: Waste of time. Not so much choice for food, poor quality of food, and the service is awful. Bellagio cost just as much, and is 10 times better. This place used to be decent, but is totally junk now. Avoid all buffets that part of buffet of buffets, 24 hr all you can eat. If you want to try buffet, either Wynn or Bellagio. The rest are horrible and not worth timenor money

JivNlMshp8HztLwaLohUXQ.text: Stood in line for an hour. Plenty of tables available. No one is being seated. I don't care if the food is going to be good here or not, I will NEVER return to this place.

lImGQ8hVi-FtB61_sNQBWQ.text: Yes!!!! worth the price and had everything you want at a brunch buffet from crepes, omelets, pastries and more. Pay the extra $10 and skip the long line.

dafrESYXsHVbPKUyWm29JA.text: This was our 1st stop (dinner) on a recent buffet of buffets adventure. It was also our 1st trip to this buffet which I have always wanted to try.   The food was pretty good and the options were plentiful. I really enjoyed the soups, hot spinach and artichoke dip, cheese platter and desserts. The mini creme brulee was very good. Pass on the bread pudding (some of the worst I've ever tried and I have eaten a lot). I finished with a nutella and banana (fresh from the dessert area) crepe. This is what I was looking forward to the most. It was good but would have been great if the woman making them would take her time more. It was kind of a shoddy preparation. The crepes at the Jean Philippe patisserie in the Bellagio or Aria are worlds better since they are prepared with more care.   Service here was not great. It was difficult to get drinks. The scenery is very nice, one of the nicer buffets visually.   I would eat here again but would choose my food more wisely. I tried too many things and was a little overstuffed at the end.

YoHjeoEqj0Cpd7j5WHtMSg.text: The selection and quality of the food is good.  The servers are also pleasant, our server brought us two platters of hot crab legs.

Ei62yOmh5AiL9yIAQjt74A.text: We used a groupon for lunch.  We dont normally do buffets unless we have a coupon and I thought it was 1 of the better buffets in Vegas.  Food was very fresh.

sDicmcLEtnZ6yV3fpLMwkA.text: My family and I did the Buffet of Buffets thing when we went to Vegas a few weeks ago and we ended up here the most.  The food was excellent. Though the fare doesn't really stray into different ethnic cuisines, what's there is fantastic. I can't speak as to the authenticity of the regional variations of French cuisine that Le Village boasts, but it is certainly enough to have quite a selection.  Breakfast: Crepes. The crepes were amazing. So light, fluffy and STUFFED with your choice of fruits and fillings. Make sure to try the prime rib hash and their eggs benedict!   Dinner: The prime rib was my favorite in all of Vegas. It was juicy, flavorful, tender, medium rare and just...mmm..... Various other accouterments of potatoes etc. were also fantastic. I did not get a chance to sample the crab. Most everything else in terms of entrees was also very good.  The desserts were sooooooooooooooo good. My girlfriend and I actually ended up coming back for creme brulee and frozen custard way after dinner, just because we could with the Buffet of Buffets pass.   Service was decent. Felt a little lonely sometimes waiting for refills in small groups, but when I went in large groups with my young niece and nephew, the waitresses were kind and attentive. A floor manager, whose name I was not able to get, was also very kind and brought us some small boxes of Fruit Loops for the kids when they weren't really enjoying the other breakfast foods.

f2XMFMnCinLKow5qCzVNnw.text: Came here during labor day weekend, and ended up here because all the other buffet had 2 hour waits.  for $38 it was pretty disappointing.  the only descent protein was prime rib, roast turkey which were dismal.  i didn't love the potatoes au gratin either.  who can dislike potatoes.  their mash potatoes had lumps.  the king crab legs were tiny and cold.  the shrimp cocktail was okay.  not a lot of seafood variety at all.  the only descent thing was their crepe - the batter was really nice.  and their creme brulee was really decandent.   if i was patient, i would have gone to Caesars and shelled out $10 more.

nG_n7hz7_Gh6nNzVc3NBNQ.text: This is really good! Especially compared to HP. You can trust me, or you can go to both Le and HP, then you will trust me. Enjoy~

fvfgphywybWfxx8RDjLU0g.text: Went there this evening. 7 pm reservation, which they didn't have, and didn't bother to look. It wasn't busy so we got seated fairly quickly. First we walked around, and while the decor is cute, some of the dishes were empty, or looked picked through. For $32/pers I don't expect caviar and foie gras but I do expect appealing dishes. The pate 'station' is a joke (one pate, sliced and 'tossed' in a big serving bowl).  The cheese bowl next to it has pepper jack, Cheddar and smoked gouda.  Why are slices of cheese presented in a bowl and not on a board?  Looks messy. Maybe a little effort and 3 classic french cheeses could be offered, like brie, comte and roquefort?  The worst part was the shrimp cocktail. While there was an attempt to devein them (they were sliced on the back), it was only and attempt. On my plate, 4 shrimp (out of 8) with 'poop' in them, the unmistakable black line.  Pointed that out to the hostess who didn't see to care.  A few good things: the baguette was good, seemed fresh made.  The potato gratin also good, as well as truffle mac and cheese. The dessert station looked nice, tried creme brulee and lemon tart, both tasty.  I didn't taste the macarons, they looked good even though they're assembled wrong.  The crepe station is popular and the sweet crepes looked enormous and decadent.  Overall, I would say a mediocre experience and I would not return.

-2WsITnABDi3PlqNA9v6Nw.text: We ate here last Friday 4/9. We planned on going to the Rio seafood buffet, but decided to eat here instead once we checked in. We got in line about 815pm and were in line for about 20-30min. Once we got to our table it was all good. My wife and I ate probably about $200.00 worth of crab legs alone. The mashed potatoes, mixed veggies, prime rib and everything else that I could not remember was really good. The buffet area is really large, but the only down side is that you have to leave the buffet area to use the restroom. It was all good. I know there are a bunch of other places to get a good buffet in Vegas, and we will probably try a different one depending on where we stay next time. We gave it a try and we were not disappointed. We would eat here again and would recommend anytime to anyone.

x6dt6rfCROATovqj2X5wLQ.text: I'm  not a big Vegas guy, but I do enjoy the buffets there. I used to think that the buffet at The Rio was the best, and it would still be but in my humble opinion, it has been eclipsed by Le Village at Paris LV. The food stations are arraigned by the provinces of France. They have the Burgundy station with foods representative of what is prepared in Burgundy. There is also a Provence station, a Normandy station and a Alsace-Lorraine station. Being my mother's mother's family is from Alsace-Lorraine, I am immensely interested in what they have to serve. True it's a bit pricy, but if you wanted to take a gastronomic tour of France, it would cost you a hell of a lot more than the 28 bucks, or whatever they charge these days.

7k4FoFyeP_kw5nMWItLt8Q.text: They changed their service in the last week, so we had to get our coffee, milk, sugar because it was no longer available at the table.  Also since they released the waitresses no one came to clean off the dishes from the table so the dishes were piled up on the table. Walking through the restaurant with hot coffee is dangerous especially with the elderly and children. The food is OK but the new service is terrible.  We won't be returning unless they go back to the coffee and juice service at the table.

xIuR-OcFgN1Trk15ieS-ig.text: The quality of their breakfast has decreased in the last several years. We ate breakfast here over Labor Day weekend and it was subpar. There was a lot of variety but all the food was served cold/soggy. Many of the items tasted like re heated frozen food. The prime rib was well well done. I do not recommend the breakfast.

W285LmZ7Z5Txf7uFAEqnuA.text: This is one of my favorite buffets along the Strip.  There are stations for various parts of France, with appropriate foods, which makes it fun.  The selection is huge and there is really too much to choose from.  Overall the food tastes pretty good and the dessert selection is particularly nice.    Unfortunately, the lines here are usually pretty long, so I'd suggest getting there prior to each meal (e.g. 11:30 for lunch, 5:30 for dinner) to help with that problem.  The other advantage to that is by going early, you get to pay the prior meal price, which is less (that is, by going before lunch, you get to pay the breakfast price, etc.).  Check on the meal hours before taking advantage of this suggestion.

URaM54i6tR0rGxxmkZj2vA.text: They are understaffed.  They are allowing non-service animals in !!! No sense of urgency in getting customers in or served.

PvIpMylijWr1j5VXvBX8XA.text: Worst buffet experience. Spill on the floor when we got in. People stepping over it. Joel the prime rib guy in the meats section is an ass, he thinks he owns the hotel and treats customers with disdain. Reported to the manager but they didn't even get my name and room number. I'd stay away from this place.

-jjPoStp7QIj3CI1TGjhVw.text: Great Food! It was all warm and well cooked and seasoned. Did not appreciate the service and the dust all over the area where you get your food. Along the walls and all along the corners where you get food there was nothing but dust that could've been easily cleaned and better maintained.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dust Everywhere

AldsXBy5WfCIHfuIEvuzGA.text: The breakfast is like continental breakfast included in typical free hotel breakfast. The pastry's were terrible. If you are not purchasing the buffet pass then you will be very disappointed and feel like you payed to much for this!

y7OH0mooHdxJxD5G25zLRg.text: Can't help but enjoy the French decor like a little Francois Village atmosphere with different designs of buildings on the exterior, cobblestone flooring with and sky blue ceiling.   We were seated promptly in a small little room to ourselves with three windows and our own personal server.   At least it appeared that way. So what to expect from the buffet? Zeeeee crab legs in Zeeeee butter. Le Prime rib...c'est tres bien. I suggest the natural juices they provide for your prime rib and mashed potatoes. Tri tip steak snuck out when I was almost done, yet I saved enough room for it. Slightly red in the middle, had excellent flavor and wish I had made more room for this. A great finish to our meal was the well prepared creme brulee and / or the tart with a small variety of berries on it. Superb service by our waiter and a fresh cup of coffee made for quite an evening of relaxation.  Would I return? Oui oui monsieur

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yes this is delicious

8u477xkKb08N6N3WiljioQ.text: I stayed at the Paris and I came here for breakfast buffet. I was excited to see the crepe station. They had savoury and sweet crepes to choose from. My first pick was the grilled chicken and spinach crepe. But the person making the crepes said they are out of chicken. I went there for breakfast, and the buffet just opened. How can they be out so fast? Or were they out since the evening of the previous night and they didn't replenish the chicken? Anyways I was quite disappointed how unprepared they were. I had to choose something else which was the caprese one.   The other food items were mediocre. A lot of the food were cold. The desserts were bad. They have macarons but they are poorly put together and they have barely any taste. I don't expect much from a buffet. I guess Paris Le Village has decent food for a buffet. Would I come back? Probably not. I only wanted to have one buffet visit during my Vegas stay and I chose this one since I was at this hotel. I guess buffet isn't really my thing since I can't get my money's worth as I can't eat that much, and I would rather put my money towards better quality food.   If you do the 24hr buffet pass, I think this buffet has decent food for a buffet and it's worth dropping by to sample some items. But I wouldn't suggest paying a one-time buffet price since you can get much better food at the same price.

MBmKqzHY9gjO-gyszzPeYA.text: The selection of foods was severely underwhelming. The selling point being the crab legs, were so small you could've hid 100 of them under your shirt and no one would've noticed. The service was mediocre at best despite my party being in a VIP room. This buffet is certainly not worth the time nor money. But coming here was definitely worth the continuous explosive watery number twos and stomachache afterwards. Spend your money on the 24-hour buffet run and avoid this one. Now excuse me while I sit on the toilet for the next few hours.  P.S I made an account just to post this review and warn you all.

mDw6z40Cl--bda8qv4sYDQ.text: This place used to be one of the be one of the best on the strip and you were happy to get in.  NO LONGER, the food ranges from bad to worse.   The soups were not refilled, the majority of the meats including the chicken was tough as a boot.  Very few items were good, creamed spinach is one  Service was  poor.We complained to the manager, who was only slightly interested.  NEVER AGAIN for the Paris buffet.

zd3z6x62bBOjsP7BdxPjww.text: Vaguely French decor, but not at all that country's commitment to food quality.   Not to say it's bad though. It's pretty much the same as all Caesar's other buffets in town, which are all around the same price point (except the Bacchanal). Not bad and an OK variety but nothing particularly interesting. I hoped at least the pastry/dessert station would put in an extra effort but it was actually the weakest point, with kinda low-quality versions of what would normally be better-end desserts.  One good thing was the coffee - not awesome but better than the usual Folgers / Maxwell House buffet coffee and they bring you a huge carafe of it. A fairly strong dark French roast in keeping with the general theme.

X_wxtCR5cSEccGYBurZwUw.text: Servers were as rude as I would have expected actual French service people would be. 5/5 for authenticity

h8blJgdD_b5iIHUhf_QAZQ.text: Not too impressed with this buffet compared to others in the area especially for the price

b3zTm58TzPdIQ-tqebPgwg.text: It was okay, for the strip I would expect more.  I was happy there wasn't a line.  Wine was not very good.   And choices were few for the food.  But I was very happy w the French bread. I ate mostly that w butter.

H1F9IdXLj9cTnzj1YtxVpw.text: Steak is decent and the all-you-can-drink champagne is my favorite! However, you might complain that the capacity of your stomach is only finite... Long queue in holidays; Avoid that!

gLuAU65h1B3m5jPsVEQIcQ.text: The cheese cake was dry, no personality to the place, seems like wholesale,  Although the road beef and steak was good.

1jl6EuH4CGF_m0jZPZ-NDg.text: The atmosphere was very quaint and inviting. The food was OK - some parts of the buffet were fantastic and as usual, some were merry decent. I am mainly writing this Yelp because our server brought over some napkins for my table and after handing out a few of the napkins I grabbed the next napkin to wipe my face...  I was disgusted to see that there was food all over it and it was not mine!   The hostess brought me to the manager, Frank. He was friendly and quickly apologizedbut his only comment was that he would let the staff know about it. At $28 per person, including tax for table of six, I expected a little bit more than that. I don't know that I was looking for free food, but perhaps a drink of some kind to apologize. Still no contact.

VB-szYhiDCD3AqmrXqqt0w.text: In the genre of overpriced buffets on the strip, this place gets you the best value for your money. Lots of variety, carving station, love the crab legs that are already cut for you, the crepes station is awesome, and very good French onion soup with a hearty flavored broth. Many desserts to choose from but I went for dessert crepes.   I got a great Groupon deal which included dinner and 2 drinks per person. I do highly recommend making reservations, and note that there's a separate line/entrance for those that do. If you don't, well the wait can be awhile.   I've seen some complaints in the reviews but I think people forget that most of their issues are first world problems. This is a buffet, let's not forget. It's not a 5 star gourmet restaurant. But for a buffet, I can tell you the quality and selection is very good.

kGas1a2FgBbBL-Q8aN6Rlg.text: I have to say this used to be our favorite Vegas buffet. For many years, we made it a point to visit Le Village when we were in town. Things have changed though and I doubt we'll ever be back. The crepe station was a favorite of ours. On this last visit which was early dinner around 4:45, we found some of our favorite crepes were no longer being made. the only savory choice was ham and cheese. Really? I don't eat pork - neither does half the world. I got some potato pancakes from a station that included breakfast items. When I tried eating the pancakes, I found I couldn't cut them. I picked one up and snapped it in half. I have to wonder how long a potato pancake has to sit in a buffet before it solidifies like that. Other issues, included a slice of prime rib I tried that also must have sat on the station too long, because it was tough and nearly inedible. The new drink station didn't include tomato juice and the coffee seemed old and stale. Also, the wait staff seemed stretched thin. I wondered if they cut back on staff since they no longer have to serve drinks. To top things off, I had indigestion and felt nauseated by the end of the meal, which lasted several hours after. I used to tell people to visit Le Village when they are in town. Now I tell them to stay away.

xvo4WQxds-WMJ1YSF7MZPA.text: Where do I begin? Sadly, we were only here for breakfast, but even that and a hint of some lunch items was enough for me to give it four stars. I'm pretty sure that it was $21.99 per person for the breakfast buffet, which came out to $51 something.   I'm not going to lie; sometimes, I felt lost maneuvering through the buffet because the decor was a little overwhelming, and made it a little hard to find the food. that sounds a little dumb, but there was at least once where I didn't venture over to an area because I didn't know it was another station full of food. what i'm trying to tell you is that you need to walk around. some tucked away areas looked like they were just for dining, but there was even more food! what?!?!?   again, we were there for the breakfast buffet. I've never seen so many plates of eggs and potatoes, and potatoes and eggs! there was plenty of bacon and sausage, as well. They had brioche, waffles, pancakes, and biscuits and gravy. This review is getting hard to write because I really can't remember all the food that they had out! haha. Faves? Lyonese potatoes, and a pasta dish with truffle oil and asparagus.   Their dessert section had a LOT of croissants and other pastries, carrot cakes, cheesecakes, and creme brulee. Faves? tiny chocolate cake, and creme brulee.  They had a made-to-order crepe station and omelette station. The hubby loved the two crepes that he loaded up on: caprese and mixed berry. I, on the other hand, tried an omelette with mushroom, ham, and eggs, which was yum. What i probably loved most about the buffet was that the two people who were operating these two stations were sooooo pleasant. They didn't seem to hate their jobs even though they were the only ones there to help their line of 10 to 15 people. I'm a sucker for great customer service.   Ok. On the contrary, our first server had a serious attitude. So much so that she was actually arguing with the table next to us. I'm not going into that too much because she was replaced by another server, who was able to smile and not throw straws or napkins at our table.   All in all, this buffet was probably the best we've been to in Vegas. The ones we've visited within the past two years have been such a disappointment and waste of money. Next time, we'll have to come back for dinner! Hopefully, the line isn't long, though. We got lucky coming here at around 9 AM-ish; line was practically nonexistent.

PCqkdSSRPra1An6mtG3tmw.text: Overall stale/dry food lacking flavor.... Wait staff nowhere to be found.  This isn't worth even $15, and we paid way more than that for "unlimited drinks". Don't waste your money. I was expecting this to be on par with the hotel but not at all. Very dissapointed!

DU63fB8TkLIVfGpYT9dgog.text: The girlfriend got a deal off Groupon for lunch for two with all you can drink for $36.   We came here the Monday after EDC; you're probably asking a buffet after EDC? I know it sounds terrible, but surprisingly I had a great time.   It was my first time at the Paris buffet; but I've been to the wicked spoon, Wynn buffet and the one at Caesar's so I thought this place wasn't going to compare. The wait was short for a Vegas buffet, I think we only had to wait 15-20 minutes before we were seated. Now onto the review itself!  3 stars for the food, they have a decent selection of sea food and French cuisines. My favorite is the bouillabaisse?? (spell check please haha) Our server was really nice and was on top of everything. The dessert section was pretty lacking, and it only has two flavors of ice cream.  +1 star for the all you can drink, honestly after the 5th mimosa everything tasted the same. Of course being Asian, we have to get every drop of liquor out of my money. So we went for about 5 more.   I had a lot of fun with my friends here, if you get a chance to buy the Groupon definantly take advantage. It's great value! Other than that it's a typical Vegas buffet.

NW3LqJ4VDiY91nOFH5WiPQ.text: This is a great buffet. I have tried this buffet for breakfast and dinner on two separate occasions and they were both great.  This buffet is on the 24 hour unlimited buffets of buffets list. By far, this is my favorite.   Dont be discouraged by the long line. The wait is usually 20-30 minutes.   The food is tasty and delicious. The Italian/French cuisine will make you want more and more but guess what? You can have more and more... lol.  The dessert selection is big and most of them are great.   Overall, I highly recommend this buffets.

0JFWFIhacRWissapC29tYQ.text: I don't see why a lot of people don't like this place, I thought it was pretty good for the price you pay. My favorite was the truffle mac and cheese! The crab legs were also pretty good, I like how they cut it in half so you don't have to go through the hassle of cracking it open yourself. The desserts are on point! Especially the macarons and the creme brulee! It was excellent quality considering it being in a buffet; most buffet places don't put enough effort into their dessert. Did I also mention they have a crepe station?! Service was also pretty good, they were on top of our refills. Overall, good food for a decent price. Definitely will be coming back here in the future.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Creme brûlée on point!

Uu8-nmccrnVvBzIuWPpxfw.text: This buffet was AMAZING.  Make sure you check out everything they have to offer before you start filling up your plate, or you will fill up too early, like I did.  Our sever was AMAZING.  I highly reccomend it for breakfast!

LllLdpkMRcHmtIsGhWGLsQ.text: I was sadly disappointed by the rundowness of the buffet. The wallpaper on the walls and ceiling of the tables were chipped. Now let's talk about the food, the only thing that was good were the made to order crepes. The creme brulee was a cheap version, it really didn't taste like from relay on the sugar was barely there on top.  The feed basically was typical hotel food. In order to you get our money's worth we did he said he three pounds of crab.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Old walls and wallpapers
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab legs

VkYop7mwoi_BeP5aMKiSpg.text: The buffet is very nice! Crepes are amazing, Crab legs are good, with Onion soup. Custard dessert is best :-)

YKc6R9E64IV8uu5gyt4YzA.text: The food is really good. Especially for the price. The prime rib was tender and the crepes were delicious. The deserts were good too

FHgUsws-F52Epznmo667qg.text: Really poor selection of food and execution.  School lunch cafeteria style.  Our waitress was wonderful and the workers work so hard.  Go to ceasars!  Run!

TvQxxS3d7TsWOjro-Z6THw.text: Compared to other buffets, we thought it was very good. We came for dinner. The food was very good. Highlights include the prime rib, vegetables, pasta, wine, champagne, coffee, and desserts. Our server was nice and attentive even though she was very busy. I would recommend it and would come back.

DJjtiEJ8h791nbA8HAB_ww.text: I really wanted to like this buffet.  Unfortunately, I was completely disappointed.  We arrived at 5:00pm on Friday night and nothing had been replenished.  The French onion soup appeared as if it had been sitting for hours - very little broth and crusted container - no bread or cheese to top it; the crab legs were frozen; the duck was obviously overcooked - very dry and chewy.  The crepe station was a nice touch - I chose the savory.  The truffle mushroom was tasty however the spinach, chicken artichoke crepe was bleah - and the filling was cold.  The bread was dried out and hard.  The prime rib was the star - perfectly cooked and well seasoned.  Maybe it was an off night - maybe not.

27lcBWVQcVLb9KAuTvm-_A.text: Atmosphere was great, very cute set up, like a little French town. Food was mediocre. We had the breakfast buffet and the selection wasn't huge. Crepes were amazing, specifically the brandy apple ones.

m2YKMThWKZYkLXtt_0zNpA.text: Buffet of Buffets Marathon - Stop #6 of 7 5:00 PM The 6th stop in the Buffet of Buffets Marathon....by the time we got here, I was ready to surrender. However, once we got inside, I changed my mind. There were a lot of great items to choose from....but I decided to get the Cheese Raviolis & Dessert. yelp.com/biz_photos/ZkGD... The Cheese Raviolis were very good and the Dessert was awesome. The highlight for me was the Creme Brulee....made fresh and torched brown. Nice show by the workers. yelp.com/biz_photos/ZkGD... Overall, it was a good time and good food. Too bad I had very little room left to sample more items. Return Factor - 85%

PW2kUgR3qisV4hzJ76MmSQ.text: Great food and service this morning for breakfast buffet.  Some unique items on the buffet like slab bacon and crepes made to order.  Didn't even have to wait in line on a Sunday morning.  Great experience.

iG-Y85q6B58RLvDHAgCVgA.text: Every time I come here I'm always waiting in line so be prepared. The food is good, not great, but if you like crepes then you'll love the crepe station they have.  The staff have always provided good service.

kbNAb9wR9_urEbY3vEfh8g.text: First night in las Vegas I decided to have a good food experience so I decided to yelp the "best buffets". I was completely dissapointed . I had to spend 30mim in line but it did not worth it. I don't understand why this buffet has so many good reviews seriously. I think people here like it because it's a buffet and they offer variety however don't expect amazing taste. The buffet is not bad at all but I thin i expected too much because of yelp. If you live in America this buffet is similar to Golden Corral. Noting new,, nothing amazing...

WC1DkFbqWGLvpJee8GcMzg.text: So, I've been to the buffet at Paris many times.  Typically, I've been in the morning/afternoon, so maybe it's been more breakfast food.  This past time, I went for dinner during a friends wedding reception.  I've got to say, the service was GREAT.  Everyone in attendance always had a filled drink (almost too generously) and received whatever they asked for.  As far as the food is concerned, I was underwhelmed.  There wasn't anything that really stood out... maybe the dessert crepe and the beef bourginoun.  Everything else was just mediocre to fair.  Based on this experience, I'm not sure I will be back.  In the past we've always talked up the place to those people going to Vegas and looking for a good buffet, but I don't think I'll be doing that anymore.  Oh well...

ApC33zxUP0lLf13cJYjfyg.text: We bought the Buffet of Buffets pass and started our "journey" here. We also used the pass at the Planet Hollywood and Rio buffets, and thought Le Village was much better. We ended up eating her twice.  The line was kind of annoying, and I swear that the buffets all like to take their time seating people to make sure there is always a queue. The servers were hit or miss, but Le Village is overall pretty good. The crepe stand is definitely worth your attention.  If you know what to expect from Vegas Buffets you'll like this place. I made the mistake of assuming that these places would have mind-blowingly good food, but that's just not the case. Really, it's just a lot of "OK" food.

LXqSWKjS1s67Gmb98p8mbA.text: Having come here two or three times in the past, I believe that this buffet changed. I don't actually remember that far back ro determine whether or not it's a good change or bad... I think  I'll make my final decision at the end of this review.  I guess I'll start off with what I liked- MACARONS. Similiar to many teenagers/pre-teen/adolesents (whatever the hell I am), I like to go with whatever is "in" right now. At the moment, I believe that these pricey little pastries ranging from $1.50 to $3.50 are the hype of hype. I guess it's because of how expensive it is. Anyways, there were macarons here. I think I ate 4 or 5. I understand that there are now macarons in almost every Vegas buffet, but I do believe it wasn't here before. The last time I went, there were very few pastries that I think I enjoyed. (Actually, I don't think I was a French-obbessed person then, so it might have been there and I haven't noticed.)  Well, in that case, I think I just wasted a whole paragraph. Because as I'm strolling through the buffet (Yes, I'm too full to be sitting down so I'm walking instead), I can't name one extraordinary thing about this place. Everything was rather medicore- nothing I wouldn't find at my hometown.   Most of their meat dishes were too salty. Their baguettes were sort of stale. (Okay, I'm Vietnamese so I'm used to crunchy French bread). The majority of the dishes were the same with just the sauce altered. Their macarons were actually tasting a bit stale-chewy (I don't know if any of you know what I'm talking about) after the 3rd one or so. Their crepes aren't all that good. I had "La poulet" (Um... isn't the word for chicken masculine?) . The chicken honestly looked like smashed little rocks or something. It wasn't really favorful or anything. I guess I should've tried a sweet crepe. Another thing I'd like to point out is that the desserts section composes of around 4-5 dishes. There are many different plates, but each plate contains the same thing. When I was there, it was some mushy cheesecake and chocolate mousse. There WERE chocolate chip cookies (French, right?) but even that got switched out. Now everything's peanut butter cookies. The labels for about 30% of the dishes were wrong. I think 90% of the mislabeled foods were in the desserts section, though.   I'm not a big fan of seafood, but their crab legs appear pretty fresh. In fact, the chefs cook the pasta and other dishes right in front of you. Other sections (ahem- desserts), seem to have stacks and stacks of premade, stale food.  Overall, the scenery and overall environment were pretty good. I apologize for my inconsistant opinion. There are few good things and there are a few bad things.   One of the last things I'd like to mention is that some of the French is incorrect. I suppose the creators just wanted to put conjugates so Americans could understand it better. Although I might be wrong on my part. I'll have to ask my teacher for confirmation. It's not a big part of my review, and this isn't affecting my rating.  EDIT: After going to the Bacchanal buffet, I have to add another star for its price. So much cheaper than that one. I don't care if that buffet had more options- it wasn't worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. More cheesecakes and chocolate mousse. I swear this is a different section of the desert area.
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cheesecakes and Chocolate Mousse. Only.

5J2Q2BpE2NFygHMzofoJjw.text: Long lines in the morning but the service was good. The food was okay no real big complaints.

XHMsjf0NvSLa9AWZSxH_5Q.text: Just paid $80 for 2 at Paris dinner buffett. So not Vegas like. The only 2 things edible were crab legs (chilled so it was ok) and the salmon but not worth $40. The creme brulee was blah then I though ok the crepe should be good and another disappointment. Save your money this dinner buffett is not worth $40 and no selection at all. This did not feel or taste like a buffett though from reading the reviews maybe we should of tried the breakfast buffet instead but why charge $40 for dinner when you can't back it up with flavor or selections.

E0PqBqbc29BO53pD-XzzNg.text: Got brunch with a groupon that included two drinks per person. Very good selection of meats. Slab bacon was wonderful! The crepe station was great and banana Nutella crepe delicious! I would visit again.

zj6k4KEXwNcgKssVY_1b3Q.text: Went tonight. Super disappointed. Not much selection. Not much flavor. Complete waste of money.  My husband couldn't even eat anything besides the mashed potatoes and pasta. Everything was a mess. So gross.

J89h2gbFS8qO_A2WPl-e3w.text: Food was not that great.  No ice at the drink station.  Nobody came by to take plates away. I would of liked to have ordered a cocktail but nobody came by.

fhJQcfYGofYHbjnfWUDY4w.text: I came to Vegas for the weekend and decided to try out the 24-hour buffet pass.  I went to the Total Rewards desk to buy the pass and as my partner has diamond status we waited in the short line.  We were told that we needed to buy the pass at the buffet.  We made our way to the Caesar's buffet, waited in line for a while, though shorter than the general line we waited for about 15 minutes, there, we were told that there was an extra charge to  eat at the  Caesar's Buffet.  We decided to eat at the places included in the pass, so we made our way to Le Village Buffet at Paris.  There, someone that works there told us that there was no separate line for Diamond members, so we waited for about an hour, (only to later find out that there is a VIP entrance including diamond members).    The food at Le Village was not good at all.  The crab legs were frozen, not just pre-frozen, but still frozen.  The prime rib meat was over done and hard and most annoying of it all is that I got food poisoning from the clams and mussels    I ended up staying in my hotel room for a day and a half until I flew back home.  Going to that buffet ruined my weekend on Vegas.  Getting the buffet pass was a waste of money and had I not being as sick as I was, I would have tried to get a refund.  My partner had lunch at the Planet Hollywood buffet (included in the 24-hr pass) and hated it.    Because of the food poisoning, I would give this place no stars at all.

RrBXZCY5CwmNiWkHPjApWQ.text: Just NO         Ms Cindy was helpful after she got to us after a few customers wanted to voice concerns about the establishment.          The biggest problem was there was more empty dishes then full dishes. The meat carving station was entirely empty except this nub of roast beef THAT THEY HAD THE NERVE OF STILL SERVING TO PEOPLE! When I asked when things were gonna be replaced the employee said "oh in about an hour", he laughed and walked to the back of the house. After circling the buffet for a while nothing was being replenished. We aren't gonna pay $40 for old mash potatoes and salad. After explaining my concerns she expressed her apologies for the subpar food and she realizes they're not refilling dishes as quickly.   To Management, how about not filling up your establishment KNOWING that it's gonna be more than a hour wait for a BASIC buffet after the fact your customers pay. You can totally tell from the nonchalant attitudes from the "cooks" and from the frazzled demeanor from management that this is a regular occurrence. I understand at the end of the day it's a business but people are paying for a service that is complete garbage. I'm glad I got our money back, we will obviously not be returning.

JrHFCS9B9KuYRQqvqwS2Vw.text: Wow.  Le Village Buffet is a shadow of its former self. I had breakfast there with my partner a few days ago and noticed a marked difference.  Whereas it was busy and bustling a couple of years back it was quieter than usual.   You now fill your own drinks from soda to coffee complete with coffee grounds (ew).  The eggs at the station looked sad like they've been sitting for a while.  They ran out of bananas.  The donuts were stale.   The smoked salmon was grey.  Even the servers looked miserable.  I don't blame them. No crowds means no tips and lower source of income.

6xCl6ix9YKSprSVor_m0Mw.text: Went to brunch on 12/28/2018. Used a Buffet of Buffet pass which costs $75 per person because it was holiday season.  Definitely advise AGAINST paying for a Buffet of Buffet pass. In fact, if  you can avoid going during the holiday it would be even better. The upcharge for a holiday time pass is so not worth the quality of the food you get at any of the buffets.  Pros: 1. Coffee was readily available at your table, perhaps because it was brunch time? 2. Crab legs (cold) offered at the salad station, and was being replenished so you never run out. 3. The crepe was still very tasty and good.  Cons: 1. Many food items were mislabeled or misplaced. The bacon was in the scrambled egg slot, the beans were in the rice slot. Meat station had sausage as an option but no sausage in sight. The list went on, and on, and on. 2. Crepe station offered 3 sweet and 3 savory options. One of the savory option was not available because the kitchen did not prepare the ingredient. Why would you offer an item that was not available?! 3. Omelet station was closed, even though it was Friday, brunch (went at 11AM), holiday season. A bummer since I would really have loved some freshly made omelet. 4. Many similar dishes offered at different stations. I noticed a baked fingerling potato at one of the station, and at another station baked sweet potato was offered. Or one station would have scrambled egg and the other station egg quiche. Not much variety.  In conclusion, for the quality and the food items offered, I felt it would be an ok buffet if you are paying around $28 per person (only because crab legs were offered). If there were no crab legs, I would not be paying anything above $20 per person for a buffet this disorganized and limited in options. And I certainly WILL NOT purchase a Buffet of Buffet pass during holiday season ever again because you are getting ripped off for good.

cNpEhmzHSASKcfG9PdZ1Lw.text: Nothing really special about this buffet.   The foods were ok.   The staffs are rude and lazy.   It took than three trips to bring my drinks and they don't clean the table.   It is hard to find the plates.  The crab legs are slice in half,  there are barely any meat in them and very salty.   The prime rib was good.  The roast beef was too tough.   The desserts are in the center of the buffet but no plates.   I asked the baker what flavor was the green macaroon, he told me mango.  I questioned him mango and he ignored me.  There is only one stall in the ladies room and the toilet was leaking.  The floor was all wet,  it was disgusting.

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fruit tart
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Macaroons
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sausage /  duck Le orange

bpoDpCJLCSbm2hqWcQtx8Q.text: Long line for a sub-par, sub-mediocre experience. Not only was the food terrible (hard as a brick prime rib & pork loin) but barely anything had labels, too many empty dishes, server never came by to clear our table so my mother did it herself, rude service behind the crepe counter, and there was even a line forming just for a refill of the crab leg counter for about 10 minutes. We (the others in line and I) had to step out of line to ask for assistance from several different workers and none of them helped nor cared much. Macarons were HORRID. How??? This is at PARIS. LOL.  I would've had a better experience at Home Town Buffet. Do not go here.

c8_U6r5F5mKPeMy2NHWttg.text: 2/5 stars After 7 years, the quality has not improved....  I wanted to give it a second try since we were around the area and hungry and we decided to walk in to Le Village Buffet.   It was just mediocre food and not very fresh. I expect higher quality when I am in Vegas..  I guess the upside is I didn't consume too many calories.

KzMsE8r28Qt-Swbmevxxmw.text: Ever since I was a child, my parents would take me to this buffet and I remember it being my favorite. Flash forward 10 years or so..not so much.  My bf and I decided to try to TotalRewards Buffet deal (you get to go to the 5 buffets listed in 24 hours) and went with Le Village Buffet first because we were staying at Bally's. Overall wait time wasn't bad at all!  My only complaint here is that there isn't much selection, and I just feel that the place is a bit outdated compared to the other buffets out there.

sLeOc2jQN5kShxuy8vZS8Q.text: Le Village located in the Paris Las Vegas is one of the Buffet's you have eat at in Vegas!  TIP OF THE DAY -  make room for the Fresh Crepes...You call the filling, they make it fresh WIN WIN WIN!  Traditional Prime Rib, Snow Crab Legs, Mac n Cheese, Salad Bar and endless Desserts are just a few reasons to try Le Village!   Seafood Bouillabaisse is a must try at Le Village, loaded with and perfectly seasoned.  The ambiance is super fun with the that eating outside in the town square feeling, the ambiance is one of the best in Las Vegas for sure.  If your looking for that Vegas Buffet you will remember for years to come you must check out Le Village Paris Buffet  ~ Chef Greg Reilly Approved

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Le Village in Paris Las Vegas
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Le Village Super Good Seafood Bouillabasse
Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Le Village Chef Maned Stations

o1vOVbSmnEkQJml6brOjug.text: We purchased a Groupon offer that also included free alcohol drinks. I was a little hesitant because of the reviews. However, the food was delicious!!!! They were very generous with the alcohol tickets so we gave it away. The creme brulee was Amazing! The place was very clean and our waiter was attentive. I highly recommend this restaurant!

-GuA_1F59obvZ3Oytu36rw.text: Meh.... We stayed at Bally's and walked next door to try this buffet.   First off, let me say the staff was amazing and our waiter was terrific! That was a non issue.   But..... The food was just ok. It wasn't terrible but wasn't up to "Vegas strip" standards. I expected more especially because it was in the Paris hotel.   I tried a little bit of everything for the most part. The crab legs were good (tip, ask your waiter to bring you a fresh batch to your table)... Upon request they'll do so. Otherwise you're picking scraps from the ones out at the free for all.   The salmon surprisingly was the best dish there. The desserts were great. Everything else fell flat. Chicken was dry, sauces looked old, sushi was bland... A lot of other dishes didn't look appealing. Would I return? Probably not.

80mlr1rJNhzJR4CARQKD9A.text: Unless your ordering omelette or fried eggs expect your breakfast to be cold. Way overpriced you think they would take some pride and serve their food warner. Keith the Manager was I help. Mary our server was very kind. We won't be back.

3QZlsekRbrocX4IxvIaSSA.text: Made the mistake of coming here for brunch on Thursday around noon. Was hoping for lunch but saw it was brunch. Got inside and was very unhappy with the selections. It was all breakfast items except for one or two yucky things. The worst part was that the breakfast items had obviously been sitting there since breakfast. All in all it was a terrible experience.  Yet another buffet i will never return to.

h0lLFLs7hWJC-0HiKTqnrw.text: Before my day out on the strip, this was the perfect brunch place. I swear I ate so much good food that I couldn't eat the rest of the day because I was so full. There was an omelette and crepe bar which was fanatic. I think this best part of the buffet was definitely the desserts. Each was so good I had a hard time not eating everything

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Pi3Yuz5-Oo3g0XMwC80upg.text: This place is THE WORST. The food is F@!%ing NASTY. The best thing I had was the oatmeal raisin cookie I grabbed with my hand (no tongs offered). DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY.

LlTKzJJXM53hgzvaBtpOqw.text: My sons said this buffet deserves 10 or 20 stars. Surveying our table, we collectively ate Eggs Benedict, scrambled eggs with lox and asparagus, spinach quiche, veggie frittata, bone-in ham, carved slab bacon, pears poached in burgundy wine, roasted Brussels sprouts, croissants, apple danish, French bread, strawberry crepes, tiramisu in mini chocolate shells, a fruit tart, cafe au lait, macarons, fresh fruit, milk, and orange juice. It was all good, and there were more options we simply didn't have room for. Additionally the French Village decor is delightful. We arrived at the desk at 10:55am and they still granted us the breakfast price even though we could have paid $12 more (total) for 11am lunch, so that was also nice. Enjoy the details and savor the moment. I think people who aren't happy here spend their lives waiting for a perfect pink sunrise with a flock of doves flying out of it and harps playing. We thought this place was pretty terrific.

YYD_6gQxyyyPsnJEXcJnXA.text: It's a small buffet. Now I know why the line is crazy when we were supposed to go there 2 days before Christmas. Limited selection, but the quality of food is excellent. I didn't have a lot of food that I didn't finish. Almost everything is good.   Service is not as good though. My sister gave me her Groupon that's $30 something + a bottle of wine. Server didn't notice we have a bottle in our tab so we had to ask for it. We also paid $2 even if we have the Groupon. Well, at least, it's just $2.   Get the pasta and the macarons!

photos.caption: Photo of Le Village Buffet - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy desserts! Love the macarons and creme brûlée!

OBIKvvEJSuOeS9WBIZfqyQ.text: This was by far the worst experience I have had at any restaurant/buffet I have ever been at from the east coast to west coast.   I am a Las Vegas local with dietary restrictions and have gone to many different buffets downtown and around Las Vegas and never had an experience like I just had. Upon entering the buffet I told the hostess that I needed to speak with the shaft due to dietary reasons. I had to wait over 10 minutes for the chef to come to my table well everyone and everybody else was already eating. When I told him my dietary restrictions the chef laughed and asked what does he expect me to eat... And that was my question to him I said.  I told him I cannot eat cheese or eggs and that I do not eat meat and follow a vegan diet.. He right off the bat said unfortunately there's not much that I could have on the buffet... And I told him I've never had an issue at any other casino with him making customize items for my dietary restrictions. ( nothing crazy- just vegetables with oil instead of butter, pasta with no cheese, some type of potato, maybe something else?!) but wasn't offered anything and said that everything was pre-made and couldn't be altered... Also when we walked around the buffet he told me I could eat stuff- for example- rice pilaf. I know from experience rice pilaf is usually cooked with chicken broth, so I asked him that and he said well yes it is. 3 times I had to tell him I DO NOT eat meat.   I found a bowl of hummus and asked if it contained dairy in it - as some/most do. He told me they do not make it here so he is unsure of what is in it. When I asked if he could find out he said that he would have to go all the way to the other end of the casino to find out... Really you are a Chef and do not know what is in the food you are cooking.   On top of that, I went to get the only thing that I could eat- fruits and veggies and they were out of raw veggies completely.   The service was also very slow for how NOT busy they were. Our waitress did not refill drinks and forgot to get other drinks we ordered. Plates were not refilled and would have to walk on the other side to get them.   This also is not just because I can't eat a lot of foods- the other two people in my party were not satisfied at all. I would rather go to a buffet for $8 bucks instead of blowing over 30. For being a diamond member , I would say food was not good( so I heard) , service was not good, and overall very disappointed.   The reaction/rudeness of the chef was unacceptable and troublesome that he was not knowledgeable about what they were serving. Also, I am sure I am not the only person in the world who has dietary restrictions.  The only good thing about this place was the interior decorations.

YOWdIfpSdlU5P2o48j4Q-w.text: I want that Las Vegas buffet experience.  I want that experience without the bougie price.  I want that experience without the price and with food that isn't dusted with cigarette butts.  Well it sounds like Le Village Buffet is the place for you!  *cheesy smile*  With ~$30/p for dinner, you just can't beat it when compared to other buffets that cost much more than that per head.    Because I'm one of those cheap and uncouth buffet goers, I can't say I'm a complete fan.  Their seafood options are really just cooked mussels and clams, plus the usual cocktail shrimp.  I didn't get to fist pump the air like I cheated the system after downing a plate and a half of bivalve molluscs.  It's just not as satisfying as a plate of crab legs.  If you are, however, one for variety and a plethora of options, Le Village has you covered.  From sushi rolls to bouillabaisse, macarons, bratwursts and a hand sliced steak section, there will be something for you and lots of it!

6W3sXdsT3p8rwXjmgnLsqA.text: Stuff was undercooked or overcooked could've been more variety $89 for two adults and four kids is kind of a lot when the kids don't even eat that much custom made omelette was OK the server making it was probably the best thing at the buffet. Saddened to see that everything is gone away the old Vegas I knew when I was kid is dead

aXi1GqkjjN_Rw2InSGZ27g.text: Started our 24 buffet pass here for breakfast.  Wow - what great food.  Made to order crepes and omelets, Brioche French Toast, all types of European sausages and other meats.  My only disappointment was I was expecting more pastries for a French Buffet.  The atmosphere  is beautiful.  Very open.  Feels like you're outside.    The service was the only thing keeping me from giving 5 stars.  They take your drink order when you're seated.  Most buffets have the drinks there when you return.  Well, we had to ask again for them.  Also, flagging someone down to get another fork was challenging.    These are minor things though as the food was amazing.  I would go back here for breakfast anytime.  Might even try lunch and/or dinner next time.
